body: YESSS üêô

Tried building this locally with `npm run electron-build -- --target=6.7.0` and got:

```
../src/boringssl/err_data.c:17:10: fatal error: 'openssl/base.h' file not found
#include <openssl/base.h>
```
When you say "locally", I assume you mean that you cloned the git repository. Did you update the submodules? (`git submodule update --init`)
Just going to chime in to say that I was able to build this locally and use it with electron (1.4.6, node 6.5.0).  Really hope it makes it in.

Was also able to use this build to work with electron.  Though ran into this issue when attempting to connect a client.

`electron .`

`E1111 12:24:34.582899941   13662 handshake.c:128]            Security handshake failed: {"created":"@1478888674.582671051","description":"Handshake read failed","file":"../src/core/lib/security/transport/handshake.c","file_line":237,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1478888674.582595366","description":"FD shutdown","file":"../src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_epoll_linux.c","file_line":1045}]}
{ Error: Connect Failed
    at /home/user/git/src/github.com/decred/decrediton/node_modules/grpc/src/node/src/client.js:417:17 code: 14, metadata: Metadata { _internal_repr: {} } }`

The code itself is pretty simple.  Basic electron-quick-start app with this added on: 
https://github.com/decred/dcrwallet/blob/master/rpc/documentation/clientusage.md#nodejs

I verified that this example works without electron and just running with node

OK, that looks like a TLS error, and it makes sense that that could be affected by this change, because gRPC uses a different TLS implementation under Electron. 

I'm guessing that the certificate is self-signed and uses an IP address for the server name. If so, that may be the same problem as issue #6722 (Node gRPC on Electron and Node gRPC on Windows both use BoringSSL instead of OpenSSL). If so, I think that would confirm the theory that that problem is related to BoringSSL.

Unfortunately, as things are currently set up, BoringSSL is the only viable option for Node gRPC on Electron, so that problem may not be fixed before we publish official Electron support.

That error output has a bunch of `In file included from /Users/case/.node-gyp/6.7.0/include/node/openssl/err.h`. That looks like it's building against the current version of Node, instead of against Electron. Do you have all of the environment variables set correctly?
What ENV variables do I need set? I am just running `npm run electron-build -- --target=6.7.0`

6.7.0 isn't a valid Electron target. The latest version of Electron is 1.4.6. And I would strongly recommend setting the environment variable `HOME=~/.electron-gyp`, as suggested in the Electron docs linked above, so that the downloaded files don't conflict with existing files.

Is there any estimated time when this will be done? Thanks

Update: I actually just forked it and updated the bindings.gyp file to include the library: /usr/local/opt/openssl/lib/libcrypto.a
Then I: 
npm install <myfork> -S
LDFLAGS=-L/usr/local/opt/openssl/lib CPPFLAGS=-I/usr/local/opt/openssl/include ./node_modules/.bin/electron-rebuild

And it worked
@eltoro Are you saying that this pull request doesn't work as it currently exists? If so, what problem did you see?

So I can build the electron friendly grpc with the command:

```
npm run electron-build -- --target=1.4.6
```

or even

```
./tools/run_tests/build_node_electron.sh 1.4.6
```

What I'm not seeing yet is how can I make a grpc tgz with that build that I can install with npm install on another box (or just in another directory)?  Is there some other npm script that I'm missing (or one of the many scripts in tools/)?

It's not the tarball that's the problem. That's easy enough to get with `npm pack`. But that won't contain the compiled stuff. If you have the right tools set up, you should be able to install this the same way you would install any other native module using the instructions from Electron that I linked above.
I guess what I was hoping for was a way to make `npm pack` include the compiled stuff.  Since there doesn't seem to be a way I'll go back to the electron link.  Thanks.

Running into some really strange errs when babel-loader via webpack tries to build the grpc module.
ERROR in ./~/grpc/package.json
Module parse failed: /home/user/git/src/github.com/decred/decrediton/node_modules/grpc/package.json Unexpected token (2:9)
You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type.
SyntaxError: Unexpected token (2:9)

ERROR in ./~/grpc/~/node-pre-gyp/lib/info.js
Module not found: Error: Cannot resolve module 'aws-sdk' in /home/user/git/src/github.com/decred/decrediton/node_modules/grpc/node_modules/node-pre-gyp/lib
 @ ./~/grpc/~/node-pre-gyp/lib/info.js 14:14-32

etc...

All the other installed modules appear to build fine, but grpc's can't seem to parse even the simplest of js or json.

I'm currently installing it via: "grpc": "file:../grpc"  and that dir has this PR branch checked out currently
https://github.com/alexlyp/decrediton/tree/ayp_framework

I did notice some inexplicable issues when trying to use watchify + babelify with grpc as well.  It would bundle everything nicely, then a random '_handle' not defined somewhere in that 100K bundle.js 

Would go away when I commented out the import grpc

I don't know what babel-loader does, so I don't know why it doesn't work. But the babel-loader page seems to indicate that you should be excluding `node_modules` from whatever it does, so you shouldn't be building your dependencies. It may be that your `file: "../grpc"` pointer is bypassing that.

@murgatroid99 any idea whether or not we can provide some instructions on back-porting this to the VS code team? I'm currently trying to create an extension which uses GRPC and the dll errors persist.

Thank you @murgatroid99 for this patch.

I was able to successfully build the module from source, for electron 1.4.11 on OSX Sierra, node v6.5.0

The grpc module is loaded successfully in the electron app and works as expected.

There is an error however when trying to run `npm test` .

Any ideas?

grpc@1.1.0-dev test /Users/dev/Electron.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/grpc
mocha src/node/test && npm run-script lint

module.js:583
  return process.dlopen(module, path._makeLong(filename));
                 ^
Error: Module version mismatch. Expected 48, got 50.
    at Error (native)
    at Object.Module._extensions..node (module.js:583:18)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:424:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/dev/Electron.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/grpc/src/node/src/grpc_extension.js:38:15)

..... snip .....

npm ERR! Test failed.  See above for more details.

Are you sure `npm test` is using Electron and not Node? Either way, that error indicates a version mismatch between the version of Electron that you built for and the version of Electron/Node that you're running.
I'm not sure as a matter of fact. What would be the right command line to run `npm test` using electron?

It looks like you installed gRPC as a dependency for your own app, and you're running `npm test` for that app. If that's accurate, you should just do what you normally do to run your tests on Electron.

If you're asking how to run the gRPC tests in the gRPC repository using electron, you should be able to do something like this (assuming you have electron installed globally)

```sh
electron ./node_modules/.bin/electron-mocha src/node/test
```

Yes that is what I was looking for:

```
electron ./node_modules/.bin/electron-mocha src/node/test
```

All unit tests are passing :+1:

Hope to see this merged soon.
test this please
@murgatroid99 we've been using this branch on both Linux and OSX for a week or two with no issue (just in case that helps).
Works like a charm! This is a great pull request, thank you @murgatroid99.
Is there an ETA on when this will be merged in?

@murgatroid99 Is there anything on the dev front you need to help get this in?  We've been using it for decred/decrediton and all seems well for us but of course I'd be happier with something in master (and would be more than happy to help with anything if needed).
